title: OceanGate Titan Submarine Incident (June 2023)
description: A crewed submersible vessel designed by OceanGate to carry researchers and tourists to the Titanic wreck (~3,800 m depth). The onboard software controls navigation, life‑support, pressure monitoring, and emergency systems.
objectives:
Safety and Fault Tolerance — software must detect anomalies in hull pressure, structural integrity, life‑support, and safely handle failures.

Reliability under high pressure — system must maintain operation and accuracy under extreme depth and pressure.

Real‑time Monitoring and Alerting — immediate detection of out‑of‑range sensor data and automated emergency responses.
test_plan:
Unit tests on sensor-read modules: verify zero, out-of-range, and corrupted inputs.

Integration tests: entire life‑support and navigation software on hardware-in-the-loop or high‑fidelity simulators.

Fault‑injection tests: simulate communications dropouts, erroneous sensor outputs, power loss, memory corruption.

Stress/duration tests: simulate continuous 48+ hour deep-sea mission.

Emergency procedure tests: verify automated response on pressure spike, critical oxygen drop, or structural compromise.
defect_management:
All identified defects logged in a centralized tracking system (e.g., JIRA) with severity classifications.

High-severity issues (safety-critical) must have patches or mitigations before any launch.

Root-cause analysis required for any failure in test; findings must be approved by Software Safety Engineer.
reviews:
Peer code reviews are mandatory for all safety-critical modules.

Safety audits per IEC 61508 by an independent safety assessor before deployment.

Design reviews with cross-functional teams (software, mechanical, systems, QA) at completion of major risk zones (e.g., 10k LOC, new feature modules).
supplier_control:
External sensor/hardware suppliers must provide documentation, interface specifications, and evidence of testing at full-depth conditions.

Software libraries and third-party components must have signed SBOMs and documented licenses.

All supplier deliverables undergo integration tests before acceptance.
references:
Taub, B. (2023, July 1). The Titan submersible was “an accident waiting to happen”. The New Yorker. https://www.newyorker.com/news/a-reporter-at-large/the-titan-submersible-was-an-accident-waiting-to-happen

purpose: To ensure the Titan submersible’s software is reliable, safe under extreme conditions, and capable of detecting or mitigating failures, preventing a catastrophic incident like hull breach or life‑support failure.
